One of our youth film critics reviewed this and here is what she had to say:

Gone is the new PG-13 thriller/horror starring Amanda Seyfried. It's about a woman named Jill who was snatched out of her bed by a serial killer and had to fight for survival and escape. A few years later Jill's sister goes missing and she is convinced it is the same man who took her years before. Jill will stop at nothing to save her sister from a gruesome fate and catch the serial killer behind multiple kidnappings.

I really enjoyed this film and although it was technically in the thriller/horror genre I didn't find it all that frightening. I thought the cinematography and soundtrack was good in the sense that it enhanced the suspense of the movie. I don't think I have a favorite scene because the whole film was very captivating and clever.

My favorite character is Jill played by Amanda Seyfried because she is very good at out smarting the ones around her and she is very clever. Plus she really handles the situation that she is in with a level head and she never gives up even though everyone around her doubts her and tells her she is crazy. Overall I give Gone 4 out of 5 stars and recommend this film for ages 13 and up due to suspense, intense situations and mild violence.

Reviewed by Raven D, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic

In "Gone," Amanda Seyfried stars as Jill Parrish, a kidnapping survivor who was forcefully taken from her home and imprisoned in a deep hole in a heavily wooded area, where she found the remains of other victims.  She managed to escape, but a year later, her sister Molly (Emily Wickersham) goes missing and Jill is convinced that the same man had come back looking for her.  She goes to the police but her suspicions are tough to prove, since there was never any evidence found concerning her own kidnapping.

Over the last year, Jill has been seeing a psychotherapist to help her overcome lingering fears. Still, she keeps files of local missing persons and dogs the police whenever she believes she has leads.  The police now think of her as a nuisance and a paranoid nut case.

The plot of this film is shamelessly cribbed from any number of Hitchcock classics about a victim who cannot go to the authorities and must enter into dangerous situations alone to discover the identity of the bad guy(s).  The dramatic point in the Hitchcock pictures was placing an average Joe or Jill in extraordinary situations.  Director Heitor Dahlia does the same with her Jill, but makes her more avenging warrior than frightened girl.  She packs a .38, concocts on-the-spot lies to gather information, and has detective skills and instincts that would make Sherlock Holmes seem an amateur.  We never buy her as a real character, merely Hollywood's mannequin substitute for one.

Ms. Seyfried is an actress (and I use the term lightly) with one expression -- wide-eyed, deer-in-the-headlights terror.  This ceases to be effective since, after a couple of scenes, she comes off more as a saucer-eyed cartoon than a woman determined to find her missing sister.  We should be rooting for her, but she becomes more and more irritating as the film progresses.

This routine thriller lacks a key ingredient -- suspense.  The narrative is essentially a police procedural, minus the police.  We see Jill travel throughout Portland, Oregon, attempting to piece together clues that might lead her to Molly.  Assorted unsavory or suspicious characters are introduced, any one of whom might be the serial killer, but when the tension should increase and suspense should be at its peak, the movie coasts along into familiar, cliched territory.

Another significant flaw is the identity of the serial killer.  In "Silence of the Lambs," the film it aspires to, Buffalo Bill was a real character -- vile and horrifying, but a solid character nonetheless.  In "Gone," we learn little about the killer, see him even less, and so aren't horrified by him at all.  Call him the generic serial killer.  Though it would be unsettling, it might be interesting to find out why this guy goes to such efforts to kidnap and imprison young women.

"Gone" has a couple of good supporting performances, by Jennifer Carpenter as a friend of Jill and Daniel Sunjata as a detective who investigated Jill's original claims of being abducted.  They are talented actors who deserve much better material.

A thriller customarily builds to a climax -- a peak of dramatic action.  The "big" sequence in "Gone" is a terrible disappointment and makes the viewer wonder why he invested time and money to see the movie.  This undistinguished PG-13 rated picture is a collection of obvious red herrings, contrived situations, unlikely encounters, and overly zealous vigilantism.

Amanda Seyfried is waitress Jill who has nightmares of a past abduction. She lives with her sister Molly (Emily Wickersham) who is the smart sane sensible one of the two. When Molly goes missing, Jill goes into a frenzy thinking she too has been abducted by the same guy, even though the MO appears to be  different.

Amanda is a bit flighty when she goes to the police with her 1 hour missing sister story. Because there was no evidence from her last abduction...if fact it was contrary to her story, the police show reluctance to help Amanda, telling her to come back Monday if her sister is still missing. She also has a history of "Crying Wolf." Amanda is convinced it is the same guy who abducted her, and her sister is going to be killed tonight if she doesn't find her and the killer. Officer McKay seems willing to help, but his interest in Amanda comes across as less than professional and is suspect to anyone who watches these films. Molly's boyfriend (Sebastian Stan) has his doubts too and appears less than concerned as suspects mount. To add to that list of suspects there is the creepy neighbor as well as the creepy locksmiths.

Armed with information from the creepy neighbor and a .38 Amanda won't sleep until the abductor is found.

The ending was fine, but it needed a final Hitchcock twist. Seyfried looked stellar in a sea of prop actors.

Not since I saw the Halle Berry movie The Call have I been so shocked by a movie's ending! Pleasantly shocked, but shocked nonetheless! This is a movie about a woman who endured a horrible kidnapping and was able to dupe the kidnapper and barely escape with her life. Years later after her parents were killed in an accident Jill has a nervous breakdown and was committed to a psychiatric ward.

SPOILER ALERT!!  SPOILER ALERT!!

After she was released from the psychiatric ward, Jill goes to live with her kid sister, Molly. But upon returning home from work after the graveyard shifts he notices Molly gone. Her clothes and books are untouched and Jill realizes that her sister has been taken. Going to the police is no help as they do not believe her story. Left to her own devices, she tracks down leads and gets her clues through fast talk, deception, brute force and using her feminine wiles on many an unsuspecting male. She's intelligent, too. When attempting to procure information she's able to change her stories to match whichever individual she is conversing with (Her Bike Was Stolen, Someone Clipped Her Car, Her Grandfather Has Dementia And is Missing) and this allows her pleas to be believed and people willingly assist her. The scene with the fellow who lends her his truck is hilarious! Yet it's believable because as males we are all susceptible to a beautiful woman's feminine wiles--and cash! I liked the comic relief: "What does it mean if you don't return it?" he asks. "It means I'm dead," she says, driving away.

Jill eventually has to ditch the truck but goes to her girlfriend for assistance in borrowing her car. She also gets the telephone number of the killer. She calls him and he lures her to his bolt hole deep in the Oregon Forest. There she finds a campsite with evidence of the man's dastardly doings. Seeing a lantern burning up ahead, Jill is lured to the edge of a pit and then thrown down. The killer climbs down to skewer Jill with the leg bone she once used to stab him but is outwitted by Jill as she shoots him twice and then climbs out of the pit, this time pulling up the rope ladder. Demanding to know what happened to her sister, Jill shoots him again, this time through the leg and threatens to shoot him a fourth time. The man relents and tells Jill what she wants to know. Begging for his life, Jill returns to the lip of the pit and pours kerosene down upon the helpless man, still pleading for his life. "You said you'd let me live!" he weeps. "I lied!" Jill says with unequivocal triumph. Wow!

I was so shocked when I saw what she did! Burning the poor guy alive was so cruel! Granted, if anyone deserved this fate it would be him. Yet to see a man begging for his life that had been shot thrice with a .38 special it makes me shudder to think of his agony as he died in flames.

The cover of the DVD says: "Nothing can stop her." They are right. Jill is tenacious, clever, agile, conniving and adaptable to her situation(s). This was necessary for her to get to the bottom of what happened to her sister. Yet, ironically she was only playing into the psychopath's hands as he sought only to recapture Jill.

The mistakes the man made. First of all, after duping and dumping her into the pit, he should have assumed she would have had some sort of weapon with her--either a knife or a gun. This leads me to the second mistake the fellow made. He should never have gone back down into the pit--at least not immediately. The darkness made it all but impossible to tell if she was armed and by the time he reached to bottom of the pit it was he who was trapped and at Jill's mercy! Having that gun is what saved Jill's life. Every woman in America should carry a .38 for protection. It would all but guarantee their safety from being abducted by strangers or even raped. I loved this movie and I'm proud to be the 118th person to give this a Five Star review and the 315th person overall to review this film. Buy it and you won't be disappointed.

One last thing. I didn't even recognize one of my favorite actors from back in the day. Michael Pare, who played Lieutenant Bozeman! He's come a long way from Houston Knights. But I enjoyed his supporting role and loved all of the characters in the film.

Jill Parrish (Amanda Seyfried) is kidnapped from her bed one night, but manages to escape her kidnapper. When she tries to move on with her life after the horrifying incident that has left her paranoid, she cant help feeling that her kidnapper is hiding just around the corner. When Jill comes home from work to find her sister missing, she does what any normal person would: she goes to the police. Suddenly, everywhere Jill turns, people are looking at her like she is just a paranoid mess. So when the police won't listen to her, Jill takes the investigation of her missing sister into her own hands. Living in a world where everyone she knows thinks she is crazy isn't easy for Jill, especially when she knows her sister has been kidnapped by the same man who tried to kidnap her. With the cops hot on her trail they aren't looking for her sister. The cops are only willing to look for the girl that theyve labeled as crazy, leaving Jill to be the only person willing to save her sister. Its a race against time as Jill fights to save her sisters life, but will she be too late? How far is she willing to go to find the kidnapper, and if she does, what is she prepared to do to save her sister? Is the killer even real or is he just a figment of her imagination, just like everyone has been trying to tell her all along? After all, Jill does stop taking the pills that are meant to keep her sane.

Like a 2005 Jodie Foster thriller "Flightplan," Amanda Seyfried's "Gone" starts out well, with a heroine desperately looking for a missing person. Her struggle to find out the truth is made doubly difficult because no one around her believes what she says. This is an intriguing, Hitchcock-like premise, and Brazilian director Heitor Dhalia manages to keep the ball rolling until the final act where the story, so far pretty good, suddenly fizzles.

Amanda Seyfried plays Jill Parrish, a Portland girl who was abducted and imprisoned in a hole somewhere in Forest Park. She escapes, but the terrible event still haunts her. Well, that's what she says. The local police, however, do not believe that. They could not locate the hole in the forest. Besides that, Jill was once in a psychiatric institution.

It is only natural that the police officer Sgt. Powers (Daniel Sunjata) is skeptical when Jill claims her college student sister Molly (Emily Wickersham) is kidnapped. She is not at home. She has missed the test. The police think she will eventually come back. Jill does not think so and starts her own investigation alone.

Despite the countless plot holes, pointless car chase and some incredible incompetence on the part of the police, "Gone" remains entertaining, except the last chapter where our heroine is finally given a chance to do what she wants to do, she does it in the blandest and most forgettable way imaginable. Well, that's it? Is that all?

I liked "Gone" for what it is, a B-thriller with Amanda Seyfried. This is a great way to kill time on a rainy day afternoon.

Ah, it's one of those just-because-you're-paranoid-doesn't-mean-that-someone's-not-out-to-get-you flicks.  And it's bad enough when you've got a serial killer chasing you, but it's really bad when you have embarrassed and under qualified cops chasing you as well.  Now, how're you going to outsmart them both?

Well, easy.  All you've got to do is have a dumb serial killer and some dumb cops.  And we've got some of both going on here; after all, we're in Portland.  But you also need a smart chick, at least a street smart one.  And we've got one of those as well.

And that smart chick would be Amanda Seyfried, who really showed off her assets in "Chloe" -- a film that didn't necessarily give her career a boost, something that can't be said for the male audience of that thriller, however -- gives a kick-tail-and-take-names performance here as a gal who has to fight off a serial killer.  Twice.  You'd think that her killer wannabe would have thunk twice about taking her on twice.  But remember, he wasn't all that sharp.  Or perhaps he just wanted to see her again.  Can't say I blame him.

It's interesting that they filmed this in Portland.  After all, there haven't been that many serial killers from there, have there?  Let's see. . . .  1.  I-5 Killer, aka Randall Woodfield.  2.  Happy Face Killer, aka Keith Hunter Jesperson.  3.  Green River Killer, aka Gary Ridgway (to be fair, I think that he just dumped one body in that area to confuse the police.)  Looks like there have been quite a few more than that, peeking around the web.  So I guess that Portland is as good a place as any to set this film. During the opening credits we meet Jill Conway (Amanda Seyfried) walking through a dense forest, map in hand, searching for something. Jill is a young Portland woman who lives with her sister, recovering alcoholic Molly (Emily Wickersham). The year before, Jill was kidnapped by a serial killer who abandoned her in a hole in the forest, where she found human remains. When her abductor descended into the hole to kill her, Jill was able to stab him with a bone and climb his rope and return to civilization. However, the police didn't find the hole and discovered that Jill had been committed to a psychiatric institution for several years after her parents' death. Believing that the abduction only happened in Jill's head, they closed the case. Yet one day, after returning home from work at a local diner, where she and her friend Sharon Ames(Jennifer Carpenter) are generously tipped by a regular customer about to move out of town, Jill finds Molly gone and is unable to reach her boyfriend, Billy (Sebastian Stan). Knowing that Molly wouldn't leave the house with Jill absent and that she had an important test the following day, Jill becomes convinced that the man who took her has now captured Molly and heads to the police station to ask for help, but Sargent Powers (Daniel Sunjata) and Detective Erica Lonsdale (Katherine Moennig) dismiss her claims and promise to look into the case after a few days: Jill claims it will be too late by then. Before she leaves, newcomer Detective Peter Hood (Wes Bentley) pulls her aside and tells her he believes her, giving Jill his card in case she needs help.

Jill is convinced that the man who abducted her has also abducted Molly, believing he was finally getting Jill to kill her. Despite the lack of support and help from the police who insist she is insane, Jill sets out on a thorough investigation and life threatening chase (both from the police who feels she is dangerous when they discover Jill is carrying a gun) and from people she meets along the way. How the story ends is brilliant writing, but to reveal more would ruin the suspense. Director Heitor Dhalia paces his excellent cast well and there are many conflicting clues in addition to Jill's uncanny ability to create false scenarios to gain information. This is a first class film on every level, especially making the point that the police too often view victims as hysterical and dismiss their interest in unsolved cases. Highly Recommended.  Grady Harp, June 13

Despite the fact that this story has been done a bit too often, that the police were uninterested to the point of it being unbelievable, and that occasionally, the story was a bit choppy, I have to say that I really liked it. "Gone" is one of those classic flicks that you had no idea existed but rent because you see a few familiar names in the cast.  It was actually Wes Bentley's name that caught my eye, though he has an awkward and brief appearance here.  The film is held completely on the shoulders of Amanda Seyfried and I think she nails it.  She commands your attention here -- frazzled, distraught, and then cold-bloodedly bold and almost dangerously zealous to find her sister.  I remember Seyfried from back in her "Veronica Mars" days and I was impressed with her.  A lot of credit has to go to director Heitor Dhalia.  This movie DRIPS with atmosphere.  The man knows how to make the little hairs on the back of your neck stand up.  Every scene has a creepy, voyeuristic, something-bad-is-going-to-happen-at-any-moment feel.
The movie boils down to Seyfried's desperate attempt to find her sister, and the actress makes it all worth watching, even when it's preposterous.  I won't give it away, but there's a really cool thing that happens in the end, where the film quiets down and the frenzy stops.  There's something so scary and odd about the scenes, but I only wish they would have lasted longer.  They are soon dashed for a much more conventional -- and quite frankly disappointing -- finale.
My biggest issue with the film is some of the basic weirdness when dealing with the police.  The cops seem solely focused on Amanda's character but ignore the obvious: her sister is clearly missing and a mountain of evidence points to something sinister having happened to her.
But it's actually a pretty good little popcorn flick thanks to its lead actress and its director, who elevate the material above its script.

Amanda Seyfried has been an actress on the rise for years, going back to 2004's "Mean Girls" and the 2008 film musical rendition of "Mamma Mia", but for me one of her breakthrough rolls was 2009's "Jennifer's Body", a horror/comedy mix where she easily outshined Megan Fox. Since then Amanda has done a mixture of good and bad films (with Red Riding Hood falling into the later category), but she's always done well in most films despite the lean material provided.

In "Gone" she plays Jill, a girl with a history mental problems living in Oregon looking for clues to the whereabouts of her younger sister who she believes was kidnapped by a killer. There's not much more to the story than that, though there are some flashbacks she keeps having to being pinned down and subdued in her bed by the killer. Once she comes back to her house from her night job and finds the sister gone she goes searching for her sister and the same killer she says attacked her.

There's the expected cliches like most of the police not believing her when she says this guy is back, the red herring suspects like the sister's boyfriend (Sebastian Stan "Captain America"), a new cop to the force (Wes Bentley "American Beauty" & "The Hunger Games") or perhaps even Jill herself (insert not so shocking gasp here). Also the pure insanity that goes along with Jill's desperate searching for her sister before its too late.

The main problem with "Gone" is the lack of punch and scares provided throughout the movie, it plays out like a really bad TV cop drama. Its quite predictable but at least the acting while basic is good thanks mainly to Seyfried and Bentley. The ending is also a bit of a joke as a lot of loose ends got tied up in a fairly silly manner. * out of 4 stars.

Poor Amanda Seyfried can't seem to catch a break. After being cast in a couple of box office hits like Mean Girls and Mamma Mia as well as a series regular on HBO's critical darling Big Love, this girl seemed destined for stardom. But somewhere along the way, she hit a few bumps that has really taken the glow off of her roster; namely a few big bombs like Jennifer's Body, In Time, Chloe, Red Riding Hood (though I found that movie to be much better than Dear John but the box office receipts say otherwise) and now Gone.  And its a real shame to because she really is a good actress Perhaps it's time for her to find a better agent before what's left of her career becomes unsalvageable.

  In Gone, she plays small town waitress Jill who returns home one morning to find her sister Molly has vanished. All of her things are in place and all the doors and windows are locked but as soon as she finds an earring on the floor, Jill immediately goes into distress mode and reports Molly as missing. You see, Jill has a very good reason to be afraid. A year ago she was found wandering aimlessly through the woods claiming to have been abducted from her bed and taken to a hole by an unknown man. According to her, she wasn't the first person to meet up with this guy. Too bad the police couldn't find the so called hole or any remains to any previous victim and, after a year of Jill running around crying wolf in her obsession in finding this serial killer, they are less inclined to believe in anything she has to say. And who can blame them?  After awhile, we do see that Jill can really cook up a story as she goes on a one-woman search to try and find Molly before time runs out.  Does this guy really exist and has he really come back to exact his revenge for her escaping by taking Molly in her place? Or is this just another one of Jill's wild goose chases that will only wind up costing the tax payers' hard earned money and the police department's time and worn thin patience?  No one believes her; not the cops, not her best friend, not even Molly's fianc. But, armed with her wits and a loaded .44, Jill's determined to save her sister and proved once and for all that what she knows to be the truth.

  For what it is, Gone is not a bad movie. It just wasn't handled very well. It's a thriller and there are tons of plot holes big enough to drive a Greyhound bus through but that is usually pretty typical for this kind of movie. At least Jill isn't jumping a bus over a 200' hole in the road and still having it land and be perfectly drivable with no damage to its suspension system or frame.  The acting was good to ok with the only real sour note being in another victim to a poor agent Wes Bently. My only gripe is that the whole Mystery Man is never really developed fully so there is no menace to him at all.  And the whole ending does come off as anticlimactic. But, in the end, it isn't the worst way to waste an hour and a half. Just try and not over think it and nit pick at all the minor inconsistencies.  It is what it is. B+.
